Chapter 32, Part 2: Parables on Love and Desire

Once the Buddha was in the country of Shravasti expounding the Dharma for gods and men. At that time, there was a brahman elder in the city who was wealthy beyond measure, but was stingy and did not like to give in charity. He always closed his door and disliked visitors. When it was time to eat, he would order the gatekeeper to firmly close the door, not allowing anyone to enter the inner quarters, so that beggars, mendicants, and brahmans could not see him.

At that time, the elder suddenly thought of delicious food, so he ordered his wife to prepare a meal. He instructed her to kill a fat chicken, mix it with ginger and pepper, and roast it until cooked.

The food and drink were arranged and ready in an instant. He ordered the outside to be closed, and the couple sat down with a young child placed in the middle of the gathering. They then began to eat and drink together.
The parents took chicken meat and put it in the child's mouth, like this several times, but the child still refused to stop.
The Buddha knew that this elder had the karmic fortune to be saved, so he transformed into a monk, waited until they were sitting to eat, appeared in front of them, and said a spell, saying:
By giving a little, one can attain great wealth.
The elder raised his head and saw the transformed monk, and immediately scolded him, saying:
You are a Daoist monk yet have no shame. While the family is sitting to eat, why do you intrude?
The monk replied:
You yourself are foolish and ignorant, not knowing shame. Why should I, a beggar, be ashamed?
The elder asked:
My family and I are sitting to enjoy ourselves. Why should we be ashamed?
The monk replied:
You kill your father, take your mother as a wife, and make offerings to your enemy, yet you do not know shame, and instead say that a beggar should be ashamed?
Then the monk spoke a verse, saying:
The branches of birth are not cut off, but only used for greed and desire,
Nurturing resentment and increasing the grave mounds, the foolish person is always anxious.
Although the prison has chains and shackles, the wise do not consider it secure,
The foolish see the adornments of wife and children, and their attachment and love are very secure.
The wise say that desire is a prison, deep and solid, difficult to escape,
Therefore, one should cut it off and abandon it, not being intimate with desire for peace.
The elder heard the verse and was startled, asking:
Why did the practitioner say this?
The practitioner replied:
The chicken on the table was your father in your past life. Because of his stinginess and greed, he was always born as a chicken and eaten by you.
This child was a rÄká¹£asa in the past. You were a merchant leader who often drifted into the rÄká¹£asa country while traveling by boat, and was eaten by the rÄká¹£asa.
In this way, after five hundred lifetimes, your lifespan ended, and you were reborn as my son. Because your remaining sins were not yet exhausted, you came to harm me.
This wife of yours was your mother in your previous life. Because of the deep and solid love and affection, she now became your wife again.

Now you are foolish and do not recognize your past lives. You killed your father and raised your enemy, taking your mother as your wife. In the five realms of rebirth, you revolve without end. Who can know the revolving in the five realms?
Only the Daoists see this and that, but the foolish do not know. Aren't you ashamed?

Then the elder suddenly stood up with hair standing on end, as if in fear. The Buddha manifested his majestic spiritual power, causing him to recognize his past lives. The elder saw the Buddha and immediately recognized his past lives. He then repented and apologized to the Buddha, and received the five precepts. Then the World-Honored One, together with the bhiká¹£us and the great assembly, entered the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ« and arrived at the house of a beautiful woman. The innumerable great assembly he brought saw the impurity of lustful desires and believed in the evidence of impermanence. Their craving and expectations ceased, and they also attained the path.
In the past, the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove, expounding the Dharma to gods, humans, dragons, and ghosts.
At that time, there was a great elder in the world whose wealth was immeasurable. He had a son, twelve or thirteen years old.

When his parents passed away, the son was still young and did not know how to manage the household affairs. He squandered the wealth and property, and in a few years it was all gone. Later, he went begging to make ends meet.

His father had a close friend, an elder who was extremely wealthy beyond measure. One day, the elder saw him and asked about his situation. The elder took pity on him and took him home to arrange a marriage, pairing him with his daughter. He provided him with male and female servants, carriages and horses, and countless wealth and property, and built a house to establish a household for him.
The man was lazy and had no plans, unable to make a living. He squandered the wealth and property, and became hungry and destitute again.
The elder, because of his daughter, gave him more wealth and property, but he again squandered it as before, eventually falling into poverty.

The elder gave him money many times, but he used it improperly. The elder thought it would not work out, and wanted to take away his wife and marry her to someone else. The family discussed it together.
The woman secretly heard about it and told her husband:

When the husband heard his wife's words, he was ashamed and thought to himself:
I have little merit and was born without a covering. I did not learn how to manage the household and make a living. Now I will lose my wife and beg as before.
Love and affection have already been practiced, and the mind is attached to lust. Now we will be separated. How can I bear it?

After thinking back and forth, he gave rise to evil thoughts. He took his wife into the room and said, Now I want to die with you in the same place. He then stabbed his wife and stabbed himself, and husband and wife died together.

The slaves and servants were startled and ran away to report to the elder. The elder and his family were shocked and came to look. Seeing that they were already dead, they coffined them and sent them off according to the country's usual customs.

The elder and his family were worried and thought about the daughter not returning. Soon they heard that the Buddha was in the world teaching the Dharma, and those who saw him were delighted, forgot their worries, and eliminated their suffering. They took the whole family to where the Buddha was, made obeisance to the Buddha, and sat to one side.
The Buddha asked the elder:

The elder said:

My family is not virtuous. Previously I married a daughter to a foolish husband who was unable to make a living. He wanted to take away his wife and killed his wife and himself, dying together like this.

The Buddha told the elder:

Greed, anger, and hatred are the common illnesses of the world. Ignorance and foolishness are the door to the harm of suffering. Then the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:

Because of greed for wealth and love, they harm others and also harm themselves.
The mind of desire is the field, lust, anger, and delusion are the seeds.
